channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: In a First, Russia Uses an Iran Base for Its Syria Campaign
item.media:description: A Russian Tu-22M3 bomber on the tarmac at the air base in Iran on Monday.
item.description: Long-range bombers, which would otherwise have to travel from bases in Russia, flew from a facility near Hamadan, the Russian Defense Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Anjem Choudary, Islamist Activist in Britain, Is Convicted of Supporting ISIS
item.media:description: Anjem Choudary, left, arriving at the Old Bailey, the central criminal court in London, in January.
item.description: Mr. Choudary, who praised the perpetrators of the 9/11 terrorist attacks and refused to condemn the London subway bombings in 2005, faces 10 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Central Criminal Court of England and Wales (Old Bailey)

item.title: Tulum Journal: Evictions by Armed Men Rattle a Mexican Tourist Paradise
item.media:description: A tourist on the beach in Tulum, Mexico, close to the Coqui Coqui hotel, which was among the businesses forcibly seized in June. Takeovers of businesses in Tulum, apparently legal, have caught owners by surprise.
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.description: Aggressive property seizures, apparently legal but surrounded by questions, have shaken the beach town of Tulum and stained its image.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Dilma Rousseff, Brazil’s Suspended President, Appeals for Reprieve
item.media:description: Brazil’s suspended president, Dilma Rousseff, read a letter live on Facebook in Brasília today. Ms. Rousseff has an approval rating in the single digits and started her suspension in May.
item.description: In a move unlikely to move her Senate opponents, Ms. Rousseff promised to hold new elections if she survives next week’s impeachment trial.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Where Olympic Athletes Unwind in Rio: The Bin Laden Bar
item.media:description: José Felipe de Araújo, in window, the owner of the Bar do Bin Laden, received thirsty customers from Slovenia, Seychelles and Brazil on Tuesday night in Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: At the end of a long day competing, many Olympians are finding refreshment a short stroll away at the Bar do Bin Laden, named for the appearance of the long-bearded owner.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Airstrike in Yemen Kills 17 Civilians, Witnesses Say
item.media:description: Yemeni workers cleaning up at a hospital operated by Doctors Without Borders in the rebel-held northern province of Hajjah on Tuesday, a day after the hospital was hit in an airstrike.
item.description: One day after the deadly bombing of a hospital run by Doctors Without Borders, a family home is hit.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Under Pressure Over Aleppo Siege, Russia Hints at Seeking Deal With U.S.
item.media:description: Smoke rises from burning tires, which activists said are used to create smoke cover from warplanes, in Aleppo, Syria on Aug. 1.
item.description: Russia’s foreign minister acknowledged that daily three-hour pauses in fighting in Aleppo were insufficient to halt a humanitarian disaster.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and ALISON SMALE
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Bus of Nepal Earthquake Survivors Plunges Off a Road, Killing 27
item.media:description: Family members of passengers of a bus that plummeted from a mountain highway look at a list of survivors airlifted for treatment at a hospital in Kathmandu, Nepal.
item.description: An overloaded bus with villagers en route to sign agreements for grants to rebuild their homes ran off an unpaved road, killing and injuring dozens.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and RAJNEESH BHANDARI

item.title: Ethnic Kurds Find Haven, but No Home, in Insular Japan
item.media:description: Mahircan Yucel is one of about 1,300 ethnic Kurds who have settled in Kawaguchi, an industrial city north of Tokyo, and in the neighboring city of Warabi. Their plight offers a stark illustration of Japan’s approach to refugees.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Though many have stayed for years, no Turkish Kurd has ever been granted refugee status in Japan, which would allow them to settle there permanently.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Somali Forces, Backed by U.S., Kill Shabab Militants in Raid
item.description: It was not clear whether any high-level operatives had been eliminated in the assault, which took place last week.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Vaccine Shortage Could Spread African Yellow Fever Outbreak Abroad, Charity Warns
item.media:description: Residents of the Kisenso district of Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, received yellow fever vaccinations last month.
item.description: A deadly epidemic that has afflicted southern and central Africa this year could soon spread worldwide, exacerbated by a severe vaccine shortage, the charity Save the Children says.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Germans Arrest Suspected Supplier of Gun Used in Fatal Munich Rampage
item.media:description: Candles were lit last month at a memorial to honor victims of a shooting rampage at a Munich shopping mall.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The suspect, 31, is accused of selling a gun and ammunition to a teenager who went on a shooting spree at a mall last month and sent a city into lockdown.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: The Interpreter: Portraying Muslims as a Threat to Women, Donald Trump Echoes ‘Us vs. Them’ Refrain
item.media:description: A large crowd gathered for the lynching of Jesse Washington, a black man accused of raping and murdering a white woman, in 1916 in Waco, Texas.
item.description: Mr. Trump, knowingly or not, joined a long line of people who have justified harsh policies against a group by portraying its members, often in sexualized terms, as perilous to women.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: China Launches Quantum Satellite in Bid to Pioneer Secure Communications
item.description: Researchers hope to beam transmissions from space to earth with quantum technology, a type of communication that could prove to be the most secure in the world.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Stranded Indian Elephant Dies of Heart Attack, Ending a Wretched Journey
item.media:description: A tranquilized wild elephant lay on the ground last week after being pulled from a pond by Bangladeshi forest officials and villagers in the district of Jamalpur.
item.description: The adult male elephant was swept away by floodwaters, sending him 900 miles downriver to Bangladesh, where villagers kept him from climbing ashore.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Knifeman on Austrian Train Wounds 2; Police Arrest Suspect
item.description: A knife-wielding man with psychological problems lunged at other passengers early Tuesday on a train in western Austria, seriously wounding two, in an attack prompted by the victims' use of their cellphones, police said. The suspect was arrested.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere: Uninhibited Chinese Swimmer, Discussing Her Period, Shatters Another Barrier
item.media:description: Fu Yuanhui competing in the women’s 100-meter backstroke final at the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.
item.description: Fu Yuanhui, already a media star for her exuberant style, broke a taboo among female athletes by telling an interviewer she had her period at the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Earthquake in Peru Kills 4, Including an American Tourist
item.media:description: Police officers helping tourists evacuate after an earthquake shook Caylloma Province in Peru on Monday.
item.description: The magnitude-5.4 quake shook the picturesque Colca Valley, injuring more than 50 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gunmen in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, Kidnap Up to Dozen People
item.media:description: Standing guard outside La Leche restaurant in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, on Monday.
item.description: The authorities said they believe that both kidnappers and victims were members of criminal organizations.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gerald Grosvenor, British Duke and Billionaire, Dies at 64
item.media:description: Gerald Grosvenor at Windsor Castle in 2003.
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The sixth Duke of Westminster was the country’s richest landowner, worth an estimated $12 billion, and a friend of the royal family.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: As Canada Moves to Legalize Marijuana, Shop Owners Ask: Why Wait?
item.media:description: Marijuana smoke in the air at the Cannabis Culture Lounge in Vancouver, British Columbia, in June.
item.description: The money, politics and policing of recreational marijuana is a major test for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who has promised to legalize it as soon as 2017.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.category: National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws

item.title: Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Yemen Kills at Least 15
item.media:description: A body at the site of an airstrike on Monday at Abs Hospital in Yemen’s northern Hajjah Province.
item.description: The bombing in northern Yemen came two days after airstrikes by Saudi warplanes killed at least 19 people, mostly children.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Upset by Brexit, Some British Jews Look to Germany
item.media:description: Philip Levine, center, a Londoner, has decided to apply for German citizenship, which would allow him to obtain a passport to travel, live or work in the European Union despite the British vote to leave the bloc.
item.media:credit: Conor O'Leary for The New York Times
item.description: A desire to retain the right to live and work on the Continent after Britain leaves the bloc has led some to explore what was once unthinkable.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Tensions Rise Over a Raid That May Not Have Happened
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at his position on the front line near Donetsk, Ukraine, last week.
item.description: Russian officials said two soldiers died in a skirmish in Crimea that Ukraine denied as Germany’s foreign minister appealed to Moscow to reduce tensions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere: China Faces a Surge in Cardiovascular Disease, Study Finds
item.media:description: Men smoking on a Beijing street. More than half of Chinese men smoke, a factor in rising cardiovascular disease, along with other lifestyle factors such as changing diet and less physical activity.
item.description: The nation’s embrace of Western foods like red meat and soda has exacerbated the problem, researchers from Harvard University found.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Journal of the American College of Cardiology

item.title: Rio ‘Has Never Felt So Safe.’ But What Happens After the Games?
item.media:description: A police operation last week in Vila do João, part of Maré, a large area of favelas, during the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.
item.description: Brazil has deployed a security force of 85,000 for the Olympics, but with an economy in turmoil, residents fear that violence will soon surge again.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: President of Zambia, Edgar Lungu, Wins Narrow Victory as Rival Demands Recount
item.media:description: Hundreds of people lined up to vote at Kanyama Basic School for the general election on Thursday in Lusaka, Zambia.
item.description: Mr. Lungu won another slim election victory over his main rival, Hakainde Hichilema, after an unusually violent campaign for the country.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Valtice Journal: How Czech Wine Got Its Terroir Back
item.media:description: At the center of the Moravian wine industry is Valtice, a small Czech town along the border with Austria. Valtice is surrounded by hills lined with neatly groomed vineyards.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Centuries of winemaking expertise, almost lost under Communist rule, are once again making the Valtice region of South Moravia a destination for wine connoisseurs.
item.dc:creator: HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Court Upholds Ruling Against Historian Who Questioned Tale of Wartime Heroes
item.media:description: The historian Hong Zhenkuai, left, with a local guide, on his way to Little Lotus Peak on Langya Mountain, where the Chinese government says five Communist soldiers chose to jump rather than surrender to the Japanese invaders in 1941.
item.description: The decision, over a story about five Communist soldiers said to have fended off Japanese troops during World War II, continues a crackdown on dissenting views.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: What in the World: Flocking to Robben Island: Tourists by Day, Poachers by Night
item.media:description: The former penal colony of Robben Island, South Africa, with Cape Town in the background.
item.description: The fall of apartheid emptied the South African island’s infamous cellblocks. Now a global appetite for abalone is emptying its shellfish beds.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Hong Kong Protest Leaders Sentenced to Community Service
item.description: The activists Joshua Wong and Nathan Law were spared jail in a 2014 protest that led to pro-democracy sit-ins, and a third defendant’s jail term was suspended.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and CHARLOTTE YANG

item.title: Botched Restoration of Fresco in Spain Inspires a Comic Opera
item.media:description: The altered “Ecce Homo” fresco, by the painter Elías García Martínez, displayed in Borja, Spain, in 2012.
item.description: Two Americans wrote the work, “Behold the Man,” which tells how amateurish repairs to a painting of Jesus in 2012 brought a tourist bonanza to a struggling town.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.category: Sanctuary of Our Lady of Mercy (Borja, Spain)

item.title: What in the World: Britain’s Church Bell Ringers Don’t Limit Themselves to Sunday Services
item.media:description: Bell-ringing enthusiasts are called campanologists, and Britain has about 40,000.
item.description: The country has magazines devoted to bell ringing, there are bell-ringing societies at universities with their own coats of arms, and there’s even a national council.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Demise of a Prison Lord
item.media:description: Byron Lima Oliva in a Guatemala City courtroom in 2014.
item.description: Byron Lima Oliva’s death was a fitting end for a man who built an empire from behind bars by leveraging alliances on both sides of the law.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY W. FONTES

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Capital Punishment Is Not Israel’s Answer to Terrorism
item.media:description: Palestinians carrying the body of Abdel Fattah al-Sharif in Hebron, Israel, in May. An Israeli sergeant has been charged in the killing.
item.description: The trial of an Israeli soldier is reinforcing calls for the death penalty for Palestinian terrorists.
item.dc:creator: NATHAN HERSH
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Do Trump’s Conspiracy Theories Go Over in the Middle East? Dangerously.
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at a campaign rally in Fairfield, Conn., last Saturday.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: The Republican nominee’s claim that President Obama is the ‘founder of ISIS’ is being welcomed by the United States’ enemies.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WAHID HANNA and DANIEL BENAIM
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Brazil Bureau Chief’s Notebook: When the Olympics Media Circus Comes to Town
item.media:description: Residents of the Mangueira neighborhood in Rio de Janeiro watched fireworks during the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Some of the impressions expressed by journalists parachuting in for the Games call to mind the Onion headline “Woman Who ‘Loves Brazil’ Has Only Seen Four Square Miles of It.”
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
